lib.AmphitriteProcessCppAppOutput module¶

lib.DriftscopeImage module¶

Driftscope image class: Draws a simple driftscope style contour plot with the mass spectrum below it.

class lib.DriftscopeImage.DriftscopeImage(filename=False)[source]¶
drawFigure(filename)[source]¶

Run the program. Open Amphitrite data file, draw a driftscope-like diagram and save the figure in the same directory as the data file.

driftscope(mz_range=0, a_range=0)[source]¶

Draw the driftscope image. Top region is the contour plot, bottom section is mass spectrum.

loadFile(filename)[source]¶

Load an amphitrite data file (‘.a’). :parameter filename: Absolute path to file

normaliseMobility()[source]¶

Normalise the intensity of the intensity matrix to its highest point. (Necessary for proper colouring of heatmap).

lib.RawFileProcessor module¶

File for running cppapplication.exe to create Amphitrite data files from MassLynx raw files. Deprecated - Use RawFileProcessor_v2.py

getMassMobility()[source]¶
makePreview()[source]¶
processFolder(grain=2)[source]¶
  1. Copy raw file to working directory
  2. Run CppApplication
  3. Read text files and make imObj
  4. Delete text files, remove raw file
  5. Make new folder for processed data
  6. Dump pickles there

Open an Amphitrite data file, and check that the format is correct. :parameter filename: Absolute path to data file :returns: mzAxis, arrival time axis and intensity matrix as a list

lib.SG module¶

Savitzky-Golay smoothing, copied directly from: http://wiki.scipy.org/Cookbook/SavitzkyGolay

lib.SG.sg(y, window_size, order, deriv=0)[source]¶

Smooth (and optionally differentiate) data with a Savitzky-Golay filter. The Savitzky-Golay filter removes high frequency noise from data. It has the advantage of preserving the original shape and features of the signal better than other types of filtering approaches, such as moving averages techhniques. Parameters ———- y : array_like, shape (N,)

the values of the time history of the signal.
window_size : int
the length of the window. Must be an odd integer number.
order : int
the order of the polynomial used in the filtering. Must be less then window_size - 1.
deriv: int
the order of the derivative to compute (default = 0 means only smoothing)
ys : ndarray, shape (N)
the smoothed signal (or it’s n-th derivative).

The Savitzky-Golay is a type of low-pass filter, particularly suited for smoothing noisy data. The main idea behind this approach is to make for each point a least-square fit with a polynomial of high order over a odd-sized window centered at the point. Examples ——– t = np.linspace(-4, 4, 500) y = np.exp( -t**2 ) + np.random.normal(0, 0.05, t.shape) ysg = savitzky_golay(y, window_size=31, order=4) import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.plot(t, y, label=’Noisy signal’) plt.plot(t, np.exp(-t**2), ‘k’, lw=1.5, label=’Original signal’) plt.plot(t, ysg, ‘r’, label=’Filtered signal’) plt.legend() plt.show() References ———- .. [1] A. Savitzky, M. J. E. Golay, Smoothing and Differentiation of

Data by Simplified Least Squares Procedures. Analytical Chemistry, 1964, 36 (8), pp 1627-1639.
[2]Numerical Recipes 3rd Edition: The Art of Scientific Computing W.H. Press, S.A. Teukolsky, W.T. Vetterling, B.P. Flannery Cambridge University Press ISBN-13: 9780521880688

lib.utils module¶

Utility functions for handling data.

lib.utils.checkAx(ax)[source]¶

Check if ax is a matplotlib axis object If it is, just return it back If it isn’t create one and return it

Parameters:ax – Unknown object (usually False or Matplotlib Axes instance)
Returns:Matplotlib Axes instance
lib.utils.closest(target, xs)[source]¶

Find the index of the value closest to the target in an array

Parameters:
  • target – Value you want the index for
  • xs – The array to find the target in
lib.utils.commaNumber(intOrFloat)[source]¶
lib.utils.findFirstNonZeroXvalue(x, y, zero=0)[source]¶

Numpy arrays only, finds first y value above zero and returns the corresponding x value

Parameters:
  • x – x axis values
  • y – y axis values
  • zero – Use this to change the highest allowed value.

e.g. zero=1, would return the first y value above 1.

lib.utils.findLastNonZeroXvalue(x, y, zero=0)[source]¶

Numpy arrays only, finds last y value above zero and returns the corresponding x value

Parameters:
  • x – x axis values
  • y – y axis values
  • zero – Use this to change the highest allowed value.

e.g. zero=1, would return the first y value above 1.

lib.utils.gaussian(mzs, amp, mu, fwhh)[source]¶

Calculate a three parameter Gaussian distribution.

Parameters:
  • mzs – x axis (numpy array or float)
  • amp – Amplitude of distribution
  • mu – Mean/centre of the distribution
  • fwhm – Width of distribution (full width half maximum)
lib.utils.getBinaryReponse(s)[source]¶
lib.utils.getHyphenCommaList(s)[source]¶

Convert complicated number strings which can include commas and hyphens e.g. ‘1,2,5-7’ == [1,2,5,6,7].

Parameters:s – String to test
Returns:False if there is a problem, or an list of converted ints
lib.utils.get_mass(mz, n)[source]¶

Calculate the mass given m/z value and charge state.

Parameters:
  • mz – m/z ratio (Th)
  • n – Charge state
Returns:

mass (Da)
lib.utils.get_mz(mass, n)[source]¶

Calculate the m/z value given the mass and charge.

Parameters:
  • mass – Mass of protein/molecule
  • n – Charge state
Returns:

m/z value (Th)
lib.utils.hybrid(mzs, amp, mu, fwhh)[source]¶

Calculate a three parameter hybrid distribution. Distribution is Gaussian at values less than the mean and Lorentzian above it.

Parameters:
  • mzs – x axis (numpy array or float)
  • amp – Amplitude of distribution
  • mu – Mean/centre of the distribution
  • fwhm – Width of distribution (full width half maximum)
lib.utils.isBinaryResponse(s)[source]¶
lib.utils.isInDir(folder, fileNames)[source]¶
lib.utils.isMplColour(colour)[source]¶

Test if colour is one of the matplotlib full name colors or single letter code.

Parameters:colour – Colour string to test
Returns:Boolean
lib.utils.isNumber(s)[source]¶
lib.utils.label1dPlots(ax, lift, values, units, alignment='right')[source]¶

Label stacked plots, usually mass spectra or arrival time distributions.

Parameters:
  • ax – Matplotlib Axes instance
  • lift – The vertical spacing between traces
  • values – List of values to label the traces with
  • units – Unit to display next to values (string)
  • alignment – Where to place the labels (‘left’, ‘right’ or ‘center’)
lib.utils.localMaxima(start_index, xs, ys, scan_range=10)[source]¶

Scan range to look for maximum. If int - value to look to the right (index). If list [0] is to left, [1] is to right.

lib.utils.lorentzian(mzs, amp, mu, fwhh)[source]¶

Calculate a three parameter Lorentzian (Cauchy) distribution.

Parameters:
  • mzs – x axis (numpy array or float)
  • amp – Amplitude of distribution
  • mu – Mean/centre of the distribution
  • fwhm – Width of distribution (full width half maximum)
lib.utils.pickleAmphitriteProject(filename, xAxis, yAxis, mobility)[source]¶

Create an Amphitrite data file.

Parameters:
  • filename – Absolute path and filename for data file
  • xAxis – m/z axis
  • yAxis – Arrival time axis
  • mobility – Intensity matrix

Open an Amphitrite data file, and check that the format is correct.

lib.utils.weightedAverageAndStd(values, weights)[source]¶

Calculate the weighted average and the weighted standard deviation.

Parameters:
  • values – x axis usually
  • weights – y axis values
Returns:

average, standard deviation
